Award.AwardTitle: Novel mechanisms of plant mitochondrial DNA repair

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to provide fundamental knowledge of the energy conversion centers of plants that will allow scientists to engineer more energy efficient agricultural crops. The energy conversion centers or "powerhouses" of plant cells are called mitochondria, which are small membrane-bound compartments where the energy from carbon compounds is converted into a form that plant cells can use. Mitochondria have their own DNA, which is easily damaged and must be repaired to maintain efficient energy output. This project seeks to define the mechanism by which important gene sequences in mitochondrial DNA are repaired so that the efficient output of energy is maintained for plant growth. This project also seeks to provide training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate and high-school students, and to increase the diversity of students who are receiving research training.

Plant mitochondrial genomes are notorious for their large and variable size, high rearrangement rates and low mutation rates. How coding sequences are highly conserved while the rest of the genome expands and rearranges is a mystery. Recent work suggests a model that the expansions and rearrangements are produced by error-prone repair mechanisms while genes are repaired very accurately. Plant mitochondrial genome rearrangements and repair errors lead to life-history trait changes such as male sterility, and our understanding of basic mechanisms of repair is currently inadequate for modeling and prediction of these processes and their outcomes. The central hypothesis of this project is that much of the DNA damage in mitochondria is processed through the various subtypes of double-strand break repair, leading to accurate repair of genes by gene conversion and repair of non-genes by inaccurate mechanisms including break-induced replication and non-homologous end-joining. This hypothesis will be tested by altering the repair pathways such that mismatches or double-strand breaks are created at known positions within the Arabidopsis thaliana mitochondrial genome, both in coding and noncoding DNA, and assessing which repair pathways have been used. This will lead to better understanding of the mechanisms and pathways of DNA repair and recombination in plant mitochondria. This work will also advance our knowledge of the mechanisms and theoretical underpinnings of evolutionary change in the mitochondrial genome. In addition, this project will provide training opportunities for graduate, undergraduate and high-school students from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant mitochondria house the respiratory machinery of the cell, a DNA genome, and a paradox. In spite of being in an environment full of reactive oxygen species, the mitochondrial DNA has a mutation rate lower than the nucleus, and much lower than animal mitochondria. It is implausible that this is due to a lower damage rate, so it must be due to a better repair system, at least in cell types that can eventually lead to another generation. The paradox is that accompanying the low mutation rate, measured in genes, there is a lot of rearrangement in these genomes. The order of genes in the genome is constantly being scrambled by changes in the non-gene parts of the genome. The non-conserved and thus seemingly nonfunctional parts of the genome often comprise a majority of the genome, and are the location of the rearrangement events that scramble the gene order.

Our working hypothesis to explain this paradox is that the mechanisms of DNA repair in plant mitochondria operate in a distinctly different way compared to the nucleus. This hypothesis is that DNA damage is first processed by making a double-stranded break at the site of the damage. This break is then processed by relatively normal mechanisms of double-strand break repair (DSBR). These mechanisms include both very accurate repair pathways (homologous recombination and gene conversion) and pathways that can be accurate, but can also produce dramatic rearrangements (nonhomologous end-joining and microhomology-mediated end-joining). Natural selection prevents the accumulation of rearrangements that disrupt essential genes, but allows the scrambling of gene order. The novelty of this pathway is that damage repair is initiated by making a double-strand break, which is unusual in the nucleus except for the highly controlled pattern of breakage that occurs during meiosis.

This research has been aimed at testing this hypothesis. We have shown that even though there is an enzyme that can perform standard base-excision repair (BER) in mitochondria, removing it does not result in an increase in mutations, indicating a strong repair system that does not rely on BER. Increasing the single-strand damage level by expressing a cytosine deaminase enzyme in mitochondria also does not increase the mutation rate significantly, indicating that lesions of single base pairs are repaired very efficiently. We also showed that in this higher damage rate system, there was a small but significant increase in rearrangements, further supporting the hypothesis.

We have also started a forward genetics screen aimed at identifying genes that are involved in the mitochondrial DNA repair process. This screen looks for mutants that are unable to repair double-strand breaks in their organelles, and identifies the mutated gene that caused the problem. We have identified some candidate mutants and are beginning to characterize them.

The inaccurate mechanisms of DSBR also produce large dispersed repeats, several thousand base pairs in length. The sequences are not conserved between species (except very close relatives) but their presence is nearly universal. We characterized these repeats in hundreds of plant species, and also created a software tool for identifying and cataloging these repeats. The software is a Python script called ROUSFinder.py and it is publicly available on GitHub.

The lab has trained a number of students, both undergraduate and graduate. This includes women, underrepresented minorities, first-generation college students, and members of the LGBTA+ community. The research results have been disseminated in publications, and as publicly available data and software.
